Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Brain CTA: patchy hypointense signals in left frontal lobe, sparse distal branches of left anterior cerebral artery; DW-MRI: ischemic changes in left frontal, parietal, occipital lobes, basal ganglia, corona radiata; vascular ultrasound: intima-media thickening of right carotid and bilateral lower limb arteries; CBC: high platelet count (366-385 × 10^9/L), high leucocyte count (12.5 × 10^9/L), high neutrophil count (9.0 × 10^9/L), low erythrocyte count (4.19-4.23 × 10^12/L); coagulation: reduced plasma Fib (0.6 g/L, Clauss), increased Fib (ELISA), prolonged PT (16.1 s), prolonged TT (26.6 s), elevated INR (1.34), normal APTT and D-dimer; normal anticardiolipin antibody, antithrombin antibody, homocysteine, glycated hemoglobin, triglyceride, cholesterol; normal ECG and cardiac ultrasound; bubble study negative; abdominal ultrasound normal; kidney and liver function normal; on recurrence: new ischemic lesions on DW-MRI, encephalomalacia, SWI: cerebral microbleeds and remote hemorrhage; increased vWF antigen (182%), normal protein S, protein C, antithrombin III, lupus anticoagulant, FDPs, normal PLG activity, increased factor VIII activity; genetic testing: heterozygous FGG c.952G>A variant

Second episode: Eye exposure to coughing droplets; eye redness, inflammation, infection; persistent symptoms despite chloramphenicol and artificial tears; positive RT-PCR in eye and nasopharyngeal samples; high viral load in eye; onset of fatigue, fever, shortness of breath, muscle pain; milder symptoms than first episode; CRP double positive; normal lymphocyte and neutrophil count; recovery after 10 days.

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Mild pulmonary congestion; eye redness and inflammation
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: First episode: Positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR (ORF1N gene); CT scan shows mild pulmonary congestion; CRP positive; lymphocyte depletion. Second episode: Positive RT-PCR (ORF1ab and N) in eye and nasopharyngeal samples; high viral load in eye; CRP double positive; lymphocyte count 36%; no change in neutrophil count.

Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Bilateral diminished vision, mainly left eye, over 1 month; mild right upper quadrant pain; jaundice; unintentional weight loss (22 kg in 3 months); pruritus; dark-colored urine; no ocular trauma
Medical_Record.Background: History of heavy alcohol intake (3–4 drinks/day for 4 years); alcoholic liver cirrhosis (Child–Pugh C/MELD 22); portal hypertension; esophageal varices grade 2; no mention of medications, allergies, family history, or occupation

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: CBC: WBC 10.3 × 10^3/μL, RBC 3.5 × 10^6/μL, hemoglobin 11.2 g/dl, platelets 225 × 10^3/μL; creatinine 64 μmol/L; sodium 131 mmol/L; potassium 4.4 mmol/L; magnesium 0.74 mmol/L; corrected calcium 2.2 mmol/L; ESR 95 mm/hr; CRP 92 mg/L; total bilirubin 132 μmol/L; alkaline phosphatase 151 U/L; ALT 33 U/L; albumin 28.7 g/L; lactic acid 1.8 mmol/L. CT brain/orbits: two ring-enhancing lesions in left frontal lobe, left orbital endophthalmitis. MRI: supra- and infratentorial brain abscesses, left eye endophthalmitis with subretinal abscess. MRCP: cirrhotic liver, portal hypertension, no focal lesions. Chest CT: multiple small bilateral cystic and cavitary lung lesions. Blood/bronchoalveolar lavage cultures, AFB, QuantiFERON TB, HIV, syphilis serology negative. Ophthalmic exam: subretinal abscess in right eye. Microbiology: modified ZN stain positive, partial AFB positive, culture confirmed Nocardia farcinica. Histopathology: dense histiocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates, abscess. Special stains negative except partial AFB positive. Follow-up MRI: regression of brain lesions. Follow-up chest CT: progression of bilateral cavitary lung lesions, pneumomediastinum. Developed acute pancreatitis, acute kidney injury, septic shock, cardiac arrest.

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: High-grade fevers, weight loss, diarrhoea, joint pain; 3-month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Initial symptoms of fever, weight loss, diarrhoea, joint pain; swollen and reddened major joints; initial suspicion of Crohn's disease; prednisone started with improvement; relapse of diarrhoea, malaise, weight loss several months later; anemia detected; duodenal biopsy showed PAS-positive particles; diagnosis of Whipple disease; treated with trimetoprime-sulfametoxasole; diarrhoea subsided; 1.5 years later, lower limb oedema, weakness, anorexia; nephritic proteinuria, increased creatinine, iron deficiency anemia, decreased GFR; kidney biopsy showed secondary amyloidosis; further deterioration with bloody diarrhoea, bilious vomiting, malnutrition, anemia, intradialysis hypotension; progressive renal failure requiring replacement therapy; severe exacerbation of Whipple disease; improvement after ceftriaxone and parenteral nutrition; pharmacological nephrectomy performed; ongoing renal replacement therapy
Medical_Record.Background: No mention of past medical history, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, immunizations, or travel history

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Swollen and reddened major joints; poor general condition; orthostatic hypotension 60/0 mm Hg; blood pressure 80/50 mm Hg recumbent; heart rate 64/min; body temperature 36.6°C; BMI 20; muscular atrophy; malnutrition
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Initial labs unremarkable except hemoglobin 10 g/dL; duodenal biopsy PAS-positive; proteinuria 4-6 g/day; creatinine 1.2 mg/dL rising to 2.7 mg/dL; ESR 115 mm; GFR 52 ml/min; urea 42 mg/dL rising to 170 mg/dL; kidney biopsy: secondary amyloidosis; CT: enlarged mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph nodes; hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL; hematocrit 25%; RBC 2.8 × 10^6/μL; WBC 5.67 × 10^3/μL; lymphocytes 16%; serum total protein 3.1 g/dL; albumin 1.6 g/dL; CRP 43 mg/dL; ferritin 1839 ng/mL; CD8 deficiency; abnormal CD4/CD8 ratio; decreased IgA, IgM, IgG; elevated IgE; reduced FT3, testosterone; normal TSH, cortisol, prolactin, fasting insulin; urine protein 2.9 g/dL; upper endoscopy: severe duodenal inflammation, diffuse erosions, fistula; biopsy: blood extravasation, PAS-positive macrophages; follow-up CT: reduced lymph nodes

Diagnosis: Renal amyloidosis secondary to Whipple disease

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Full blood count, biochemistry, inflammatory markers, and tumour markers within normal range; CT scan shows large pelvic extraperitoneal mass with heterogenous enhancing solid and non-enhancing cystic components displacing bowels; MRI shows heterogenous hyperintense lesion with internal septation and cystic changes invading pelvic floor; Incisional biopsy initially reported angiomyofibroblastoma; Intraoperative findings: large smooth well-encapsulated mass adherent to rectum, bladder, and distal ureters; Histopathology: biphasic tumour with epithelial and stromal components, no atypia, phyllodes-like pattern, origin from seminal vesicle; Immunohistochemistry: stroma positive for oestrogen, progesterone, desmin, smooth muscle actin; glandular component cytokeratin positive, negative for prostate markers

Diagnosis: Mixed epithelial-stromal tumour of seminal vesicle

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Hyponatremia, hypokalemia; brain MRI: multiple scattered hyper-intense T2 flair foci in bilateral periventricular white matter; MRI spine: multiple enhancing lesions C2–C6 consistent with transverse myelitis; CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis, no oligoclonal bands; negative serologies and PCRs for neurotropic viruses; immunological tests: ANA, anti-RNA polymerase III, Scl-70, NMO-IgG positive; repeat NMO-IgG positive; renal biopsy: obliteration of vascular lumen, concentric fibrinoid necrosis, onion-skin hypertrophy consistent with steroid-induced scleroderma renal crisis

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Headache, vomiting, blurred vision; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Initial presentation with headache, vomiting, blurred vision; pituitary tumor diagnosed; received 3300 rad to sella. Two years later: impotence, joint pains, perspiration. Serum GH 16.2 μg/L (elevated, not suppressed by glucose). Subnormal serum testosterone (423 nmol/L). Visual fields normal; skull X-ray: enlarged sella. Diagnosed with acromegaly and partial hypopituitarism. Further radiation (4000 rad), testosterone replacement. GH normalized, later developed hypothyroidism and hypoadrenalism; replacement therapies started. Fourteen years later: elevated GH (25 μg/L), CT: partially empty sella, no tumor. Bromocriptine therapy (discontinued due to side effects). No surgery due to prior irradiation. Eighteen years later: progressive enlargement of hands, feet, nose; GH 104.5 μg/L; CT: sellar mass. Attempted transsphenoidal exploration abandoned due to failed intubation. Octreotide therapy started, dose increased to 500 mg three times daily by continuous infusion; GH reduced to 14.5 μg/L but not normalized. Four years later: octreotide discontinued, pergolide started; GH continued to increase. Twenty-seven years after onset: soft, painless 4 cm mass below right mandible; fine-needle aspiration suspicious for lymphoma; excisional biopsy performed. Histopathology: neuroendocrine tumor, GH-secreting. Immunohistochemistry: positive for synaptophysin, GH, prolactin. Diagnosis: metastatic pituitary carcinoma. GH decreased post-surgery but rose again. One year later: radionuclide scan showed uptake in sella, neck, spleen. Declined further investigation or active treatment; symptomatic management until death at age 72.
Medical_Record.Background: No occupation specified; no family history, social history, allergies, or medication history provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Progressive enlargement of hands, feet, nose; soft, painless 4 cm mass below right mandible
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Skull X-ray: enlarged sella; serum GH elevated (16.2 μg/L, 25 μg/L, 104.5 μg/L, 363 μg/L, 101 μg/L); serum testosterone subnormal (423 nmol/L); CT: partially empty sella, later sellar mass; fine-needle aspiration: suspicious for lymphoma; excisional biopsy: neuroendocrine tumor, GH-secreting; electron microscopy: membrane-bound dense core granules, globular fibrous bodies; immunohistochemistry: positive for synaptophysin, GH, prolactin; radionuclide scan: uptake in sella, neck, spleen
